content.body: Excited to see progress on iterator helpers
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Excited to see progress on iterator helpers

content.body:
https://github.com/mdn/content/issues/12914 is an open issue about some of the MDN JavaScript docs that we could use some insight from others on â€”Â specifically itâ€™s about the https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Operators/Operator_Precedence page, for which we sometimes get requests to include precedence information about things that arenâ€™t actually operators.

One thought I had was that maybe we could retitle the page _â€œOperator precedence and order of evaluationâ€_ , though Iâ€™m not sure even that would be enough to cover the non-operator cases that people have opened issues about.

content.body:
Iâ€™ve actually touched on this in that repositoryâ€™s issues before, too, in https://github.com/mdn/content/issues/5365. I think weâ€™ve discussed it a couple times here too; I remember raising it.
For what itâ€™s worth, it is my opinion that => is an operator in every way that = is an operator, and it is completely appropriate to include `=>` in a â€œtable of operatorsâ€ if `=` is in there too. Thereâ€™s hardly any difference of worth between them.

In reply to @sideshowbarker:mozilla.org

https://github.com/mdn/content/issues/12914 is an open issue about some of the MDN JavaScript docs that we could use some insight from others on â€”Â specifically itâ€™s about the https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Operators/Operator_Precedence page, for which we sometimes get requests to include precedence information about things that arenâ€™t actually operators.

One thought I had was that maybe we could retitle the page â€œOperator precedence and order of evaluationâ€ , though Iâ€™m not sure even that would be enough to cover the non-operator cases that people have opened issues about.

 * Iâ€™ve actually touched on this in that repositoryâ€™s issues before, too, in https://github.com/mdn/content/issues/5365. I think weâ€™ve discussed it a couple times here too; I remember raising it.
For what itâ€™s worth, it is my opinion that => is an operator in every way that = is an operator, and it is completely appropriate to include => in a â€œtable of operatorsâ€ if = is in there too. Thereâ€™s hardly any difference of worth between them.

content.body:
jschoi: Thanks yeah â€”Â IMHO weâ€™d be better off if we removed `=` from that table. But most everybody else seems to feel otherwise.

Anyway, my perspective on this is that every good intro-to-this-programming-language book Iâ€™ve ever read has a section for operator precedence that only includes actual operators â€” and then some separate discussion about order of evaluation.

I donâ€™t think the MDN JavaScript docs should be less precise or less rigorous about details like this than a well-written book would be. So thatâ€™s why I think, if weâ€™re going to include things on that page that are not strictly operators according to the rules of the language, then we minimally should at least re-title the page â€” and beyond that, make it very clear which things are strictly operators and which are not.

content.body:
@sideshowbarker: Yeah, I can certainly sympathize with the desire for rigor on MDN. And it certainly would be consistent to exclude both = and => from being operators.
I donâ€™t know if thereâ€™s any rigorous-but-still-useful definition of â€œoperatorâ€ that would exclude =, though. I think that you could rigorously define a JavaScript operator as a â€œsyntactic token(s) that create an expression but which is not a literalâ€, where an â€œexpressionâ€ is a â€œsyntax phrase that evaluates into a value at runtimeâ€.â€¨So yield is a nullary-or-prefix operator (with side effects). + is a prefix-or-binary operator. import() probably should be called a circumflex operator (I forgot if itâ€™s in the MDN table). And = and =>, I think, can reasonably be rigorously called operators, too. Theyâ€™re certainly not literals or statements, heh.

I think that you could rigorously define a JavaScript operator as a â€œsyntactic token(s) that create an expression but which is not a literalâ€, where an â€œexpressionâ€ is a â€œsyntax phrase that evaluates into a value at runtimeâ€.â€¨So yield is a nullary-or-prefix operator (with side effects). + is a prefix-or-binary operator. import() probably should be called a circumflex operator (I forgot if itâ€™s in the MDN table). And = and =>, I think, can reasonably be rigorously called operators, too. Theyâ€™re certainly not literals or statements, heh.
